docs.lead_paragraph: Mark McGwire's prodigious home-run production this year has been just the right tonic to resuscitate baseball as the national pastime and to divert a public weary of scandal and global crises. The sight of this gentle, earnest giant handling the pressure of the home-run chase with grace and humility has made an entire nation feel better about itself. But all the euphoria about his truly astounding accomplishment in hitting 70 home runs should not obscure the troubling questions raised by his use of the testosterone-boosting drug androstenedione (pronounced andro-STEEN-die-own). To some extent, the very breathtaking quality of McGwire's achievement invites questions. He did not just beat the old home-run record of 61 in a season, he smashed it to smithereens. Nor did he benefit from a lot of cheap fly balls that barely made it to the seats. This Paul-Bunyan-like character with his Popeye arms generally propelled the balls far into the stands, or lined them with such velocity there was no doubt of their authenticity.

headline.main: Editorial Observer; Post-Season Thoughts on McGwire's Pills

docs.abstract: Philip Boffey's Editorial Observer column says euphoria surrounding accomplishment of Mark McGwire, St Louis Cardinals first baseman who hit record 70 home runs in season, should not obscure troubling questions raised by his use of testosterone-boosting drug androstenedione; says issue is whether drug gave him just enough added boost to propel him to record; notes view among sports medicine experts that when androstenedione converts to testosterone in body its is effectively same as taking testosterone--substance banned in virtually all major sports
